comments.content: Maybe if you make the bird fly the other way and come off the y. Then the user's eye would go left to right. Right now mine when to the birdhouse, the tree then went backwards on the word "joy"
Connect the slur of "joy" with the bird's tail instead of the beak.

Both responses might change the message in the graphic.

The first might change the message from "bringing joy home" to "take joy from home"  
The second might change the message from "bringing joy home" to "find joy at home"

If you put both ideas together, you come up with "find joy outside home". Could you reposition the joy and connect it to the bird with a longer path?

stormbird..Interesting...but then .what would that say ? : )

Also what can I do to make this feel more holiday...the client loves it, but says it does not feel like holiday to him...since it is his holiday card that is a problem. He said he usually sends winter cards, not so much christmas or hanuka...what can i do to make this more winter?

More wintery? Take the leaves off the tree is the most obvious one. Add snow to the top of the birdhouse would be another. I mean the card just doesn't have anything wintery about it right now. Maybe use blue instead of red as a color (add some cold to it).

When I suggested moving the joy, I was thinking of the eye movement (see s0me0ne's comment).

Thick snow on branches might look nice. I would be tempted to use bird footprints in the snow instead of a bird, and lots of energy in the house for a hot/cold contrast. Brrr

Although not many plants flower in winter, some have berries.

If you have the option of 2-color printing, I suggest a blue tree/snow and a red bird - cardinals are one of the few bird species that sticks around in the winter.

Also, you mention that this might be a holly tree, but holly is an evergreen and doesn't lose it's leaves.
